abstract.p: This study compares the mechanical, tribological, and dielectric properties of glass fiber-reinforced epoxy (GFRE), presenting various fiber/matrix adhesions. Three GFRE composites were studied. The only difference between them is in the initial preparation of fibers which is intentionally simplified compared to the complex sizings used in industry. Thus, fibers treated with aminosilane or silicone coupling agents were compared with fibers simply washed with deionized water.

The dielectric measurements show the leading role of interfacial bonding in the trapping or diffusion of electric charges. To obtain high mechanical properties, a fiber treatment that contributes to the diffusion of electric charges along the fiber/matrix interface is preferred. In addition, after friction, a modification of the dielectric properties in all materials is observed, and the trapping or the diffusion of the charges along the interfaces can make it possible to lower the friction coefficient, or the wear.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to their good specific properties, advanced glass fiber-reinforced epoxy (GFRE) composites are increasingly used in high-tech areas (aeronautical and automotive industries, civil infrastructure, etc). These industries seek materials which exhibit enhanced reliability and durability (damage-tolerance). The role of the fiber/matrix interface has been proved for a long time. On the other hand, it has been shown that the durability of insulating materials is linked to the presence of trapped electric charges.1,2 Similarly, from the tribological point of view, the trapping of charges and, consequently, the increase in polarization energy can induce an increase in the friction coefficient.3 The massive detrapping of the trapped charges leads to a sudden depolarization of the dielectric medium: all the stored polarization energy is suddenly released inducing wear mechanisms.4 Previous studies on the friction behavior of GFRE industrial composites5,6 have shown that a strong capacity to trap charges along the fiber/matrix interface, inducing significant storage of polarization energy, involves an increase in the friction coefficient of the composite and in wear.

The aim of this article is a better understanding of the influence of the interfacial properties on the mechanical and electrical properties of GFRE composites, using various interphase materials, leading to significant differences in fiber/matrix adhesion. To this end, the scanning electron microscope mirror effect (SEMME)7 associated with the induced current method (ICM)8–10 were used to determine the trapping ability and motion of electric charges inside insulating materials. In parallel, mechanical and tribological measurements were realized. Thus, this study constitutes an innovative approach that permits the dielectric properties to be correlated with the mechanical properties. Such an approach has been widely validated not only on ceramic materials,3,4 but also on polymers10,11 and composites.2,5,6

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
The measurements are carried out on unidirectional (UD 0°) GFRE composites processed from DGEBA/MTHPA (CIBA CEIGY – LY 556/HY 917) epoxy resin and continuous E glass fiber using filament winding at the VETROTEX International Company (Chambéry, France).12,13 To achieve different levels of fiber/matrix adhesion, these composites differ in the fiber treatment, which is intentionally simplified compared to the complex sizings, used in industry:
a composite that includes an epoxy amino-silane (AS) coupling agent. This treatment consists of a DGEBA epoxy prepolymer and an AS coupling agent (A1100). The ratio of epoxy to A1100 is 10. The sizing is 0.6% of the whole mass of fiber. This treatment is expected to lead to good fiber/matrix adhesion due to the silane coupling agent which interacts with both glass fibers and the epoxy matrix.
a composite that includes fibers simply washed with deionized water, named W (Water) to lead, a priori, to a slightly lower fiber matrix adhesion, when compared to the adhesion in the case of material (AS). In fact, it is known that epoxy resin adheres reasonably well to untreated glass fibers.
a composite, named Si (silicone) and that includes a polydimethylsiloxane (silicone) sizing compound to minimize the interfacial shear strength. The sizing is 0.2% of the whole mass of the fiber.
The composites were cured for 2 h at 100°C and post-cured for 2 and 10 h at 140°C and 150°C, respectively.

To quantify the fiber volume fraction of the composite, the matrix burn-off method14 is used. The residual porosity is determined by densitometry. The volume fraction of fiber Vf and the porosity of the studied composite materials are given in Table 1. Table 1.

sec.title: Torsion dynamic spectrometry
sec.p: Torsion dynamic spectrometry (01 dB-Metravib device) was performed on the three composites around the isotropy axis and on the matrix cured in the same conditions as the composites at 1 Hz frequency and in a temperature range of −180°C to +190°C with a heating rate of about 1°C/min.

sec.title: Monotonic three-point bending test
sec.p: The monotonic three-point bending test method was used in this study. This method is easier to conduct than a tension test. The absence of clamping jaws limits the scattering of the results, and this method appears to highlight the influence of the interface on the mechanical behavior. Tests are performed,12,13 using an INSTRON testing machine (load cell capacity: 5000 N), in a conditioned room (T = 23 ± 2°C; RH = 50° ± 5%) The samples are about 100 mm long, 10 mm wide, and 3 mm thick. The span-to-depth ratio (L/h) is chosen to be 20, to avoid shear stress and the loading rate is 2 mm/min. Besides, two other three-point bending tests were carried out. Inter-laminar shear strength (ILSS) was measured using a short-beam bend test (L/h ∼ 5), and the influence of the strain rate on the ultimate stress was analyzed using an impact flexural test working at 0.8 mm/s.

sec.title: Friction test
sec.p: The friction tests were performed using a flat on flat reciprocating tribometer.3,6 To further-charge exchange between surfaces that are in contact, the mobile plane is positioned on the sample holder that is connected to the ground and separated from the piezoelectric sensor that measures the tangential load by means of an alumina plate.
In all tests, the two contacting bodies (pin and plane) were of a comparable nature (AS–AS, Si–Si, W–W).

sec.title: Dielectric measurements
sec.p:
The dielectric analysis7–11 was performed using SEM; (LEO 440; Figure 2(a)). The samples were irradiated at high energy (30 keV). The total amount of electrons injected in the sample, Qi is controlled using a beam blanking device. Injection time (tinj) was 20, 50, or 100 ms corresponding, respectively, to 20, 50, or 100 pC injected electrons. The injection of electrons is performed along the orthotropic axis T, so perpendicular to the fibers. The electric charges generated through the sample during the injection of electrons induce a current between the conducting sample holder, on which the material is located, and the ground (Figure 2(a)).9,10 This ground current Ig, called ‘induced current’ or ‘influence current’ in electrostatics, is measured by a pico-ammeter and can be recorded during the injection of the charges (recording every 0.15 ms). The evolution of Ig during injection (Figure 3) gives information on the different steps of diffusion or trapping of charges in the composite sample: the initial current Igmax that informs on the response of material without any perturbation, and the quantity of charges QIC distributed in the sample, corresponding to the integral of the ground current curve vs. time (Figure 3), (1) Figure 2.
SEMME method: (a) Ig, induced (ground) current measurement during electron injection; I0, incident current. (b) SEM ‘mirror’ image of the injected area. Notice the black disk (diameter d) corresponding to the gun exit image.
Figure 3.
Influence current vs. injection time for the three composites (tinj = 100 ms): (Si), curve without relaxation during 100 ms injection time; (W) and (AS), curves presenting some relaxations.

Sometimes, relaxations (sudden decreases in the ground current) of trapped charges (Figure 3), that are associated with secondary electron emission, can occur.9–11 The quantity of charges Qr distributed in the sample prior to the first relaxation corresponds to the integral of the ground current until the time (tr) when the material releases and re-emits whole or part of the quantity of charges previously stored.

After the injection of electrons, the sample is observed with various electron beam energies (V = 100–9000 eV). The electrical field produced by charges Qt, that are locally trapped in the insulator during the injection time, can be strong enough to deflect the incoming electrons in the same manner as a convex mirror does with light. Consequently, a mirror image is given on the screen displaying a distorted view of the SEM chamber (Figure 2(b)).

The amount Qt of trapped and stabilized charges near the injection point is determined using an electrostatic law that is established by Vallayer et al.:7 (2) where L is the working distance of the SEM; d′ the diameter of the last output diaphragm, d the apparent diameter measured on the mirror image, A a parameter dependent on SEM chamber and permittivity of the sample, and V the acceleration potential of the electron beam.

The shapes of the ground current and ‘mirror effect’ give information about the localization, diffusion, and stability of trapped charges in an insulating material. Ratio Qt/QIC, in particular, is linked to the capacity of a material to diffuse the charges in the bulk: if Qt/QIC tends toward 1, the charges are stabilized and the local trapping is total; if Qt/QIC tends toward zero, the distributed charges in the sample during the injection diffuse outside the injection zone and are consequently less well stabilized.

sec.title: Results and analysis of mechanical properties
Torsion dynamic spectrometry
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the loss factor, tan δ, as a function of temperature at 1 Hz for the three composites and the epoxy matrix. In the analyzed temperature range, three relaxations were observed as reported by other authors.15,16 The α-relaxation which occurred in the range 140–150°C according to the sample (Table 2), is associated with the glass transition. The broad peak located at about −60°C corresponded to the β-relaxation. According to the literature, the β-relaxation in amino-crosslinked epoxy systems is linked to the motions of hydroxyl-ether groups and diphenyl-propane units. Besides the α- and β-relaxations, the DMA spectra exhibited an additional relaxation which appears in all epoxy matrices, located at the bottom of the main relaxation peak. This intermediate relaxation, termed ω-relaxation, seems to be related to water sorption.16 Figure 4.
Torsion dynamic spectrometry: variation of the loss factor, tan δ, for matrix and composites (AS); (Si) and (W) vs. temperature (f = 1 Hz).

The analysis of the tan δ spectrum shows:
The α-relaxation is slightly shifted toward the lower temperature for all the composites compared with the matrix, regardless of the nature of the interface. The magnitude of the shift increases with the increasing fiber fraction and this could indicate an enhancement of the molecular mobility near Tg, resulting in a decrease in the crosslinking degree of the epoxy network due to the presence of fibers. This result is in agreement with differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) experiments (Table 2) and has also been found by other authors in the same epoxy systems.17
A lower level of the loss factor at the α peak relaxation (tan δmax) of the composites in comparison with the matrix. In fact, the height of the main relaxation of the composite is governed by the reinforcement effect of the matrix by the fibers, which is linked both to the volume fraction and the load transfer at the interface. The slightly lower level of tan δmax of the silane sized composite could be related to a superior interface.
A globally high level of tan δ over the whole range of temperatures in the case of the Si composite, that could result from friction mechanisms linked to low interface strength. The especially high damping factor in the ω-relaxation range is probably due to the presence of water at the interface, the adsorption of water being favored by the lower quality of interface.

sec.title: Monotonic mechanical properties
sec.p:
Table 3 gives the mechanical properties of the tested composite materials. The flexural longitudinal modulus EL is mainly linked to the volume fraction of fiber that is consistent with the so-called rule of mixtures for a continuous fiber composite, EL = Ef vf + Em (1 − vf), where vf is the fiber volume fraction and Ef and Em the Young's modulus of the fibers and matrix respectively. W 37 (±1) 890 (±30) 2.4 (±0.1) 1160 (±12) 65 (±0.5)

Conversely, the monotonic ultimate properties and the failure mode of the composite materials vary strongly with the nature of the fiber/matrix interface (Table 3).

The failures are progressive in the case of composites AS and W. These composites are gradually damaged by the failure of fibers and longitudinal splitting along the fiber direction, followed by delamination on the tensile side of the sample. The damage propagates through the width and the depth of the sample. Direct observation of the failure features on the tensile side of the sample shows there is a ‘failure zone’ that looks like two interlocked combs (‘broom-like’ failure). It is inside this zone that randomly distributed failures of fibers intervene (Figure 5(a) and (b)). These failure features are characteristic of UD composite failure occurring in unidirectional composites loaded in the direction of the fiber with good enough fiber/matrix adhesion.18 The process of failure, in the case of the two materials, mainly involves cohesive failure phenomena by shear of the matrix (specific to a strong interface) which follows fiber breakages. This is indicated by the presence of strips and matrix debris on the fiber (Figure 6(a) and (b)). The material (W) shows a more localized failure and lower failure strength than the AS composite. Figure 5.
Macroscopic failure feature observed on: (a) composite (AS), (b) composite (W) and (c) composite (Si) subjected to monotonic three-point bending test.
Figure 6.
SEM images of failure feature observed on: (a) composite (AS), (b) composite (W), and (c) composite (Si) subjected to monotonic three-point bending test.

This result was unexpected at first, because generally it is well known, that in the range of materials with relatively good fiber/matrix adhesion, the composite with the lowest interfacial properties shows the highest strength at break due to a lowering of the stress concentration in the neighboring fibers of broken fibers resulting from larger interface debonding after the fiber failures.19 This result may be linked to the difference in the fiber volume fraction but also to glass properties. In fact, the flexural failure process of GFRP depends not only on the interface properties, but also on the statistical strength of the glass fiber. The water treatment may affect the fiber properties due to the sensitivity of glass to moisture. This hypothesis is reinforced by impact flexural tests performed at 0.8 mm/s on the two composites. For both materials, the impact strength at break increases with strain rate, but the difference is larger for the material W, for which the strength at break is slightly higher than for the AS material (Table 3). In fact, the glass fibers exhibited rate dependence due to the presence of the surface defects. Increasing the strain rate decreases the likelihood of fiber glass surface flaws growing,20 leading to much higher fiber tensile strength. Therefore, in high strain rate conditions, the composites show higher strength at break and the interface properties play a leading role in the failure phenomenon.

The failure for composite (Si) is specific for the two strain rates: even if some micro-damage occurs on the tensile side (fiber breaks, matrix micro-cracks) the sample break is due to the delamination failure that takes place at the neutral plane and grows toward the ends of the sample (Figure 5(c)). The failure process is sudden and occurs randomly, which is consistent with the highest scatter of the ultimate strength. ‘Post-mortem’ examination of the fracture feature at the neutral plane displays many bare fibers (Figure 6(c)). All these observations are characteristic of a weakly bonded composite behavior.

sec.title: Results and analysis of dielectric properties on virgin materials (before friction)
sec.p: Ground current curves Ig vs. time for the three composite materials are given in Figure 3.

During the first 20 ms, the response of the three samples is practically independent of the interface nature. Then, the curves of the three composites are different. In the case of the (Si) composite, the injection of charges was continuous. Conversely, relaxation phenomenon (a sudden decrease of ground current accompanied by secondary electron emission) occurs at 37 ms for composite (AS) and at 53 ms for composite (W) (Table 4). At that time, the relaxation of charges reaches a critical density of trapped charges (Qr = 26.8 pC for composite (AS) and Qr = 38.2 pC for composite (W)) (Table 4) and electrons will be re-emitted in the vacuum (secondary electron emission). This relaxation phenomenon can be explained by the aptitude of the material to spread trapped charges. This aptitude induces the decrease in the polarization field that is linked to the local polarization energy. This field seems to be responsible for the detrapping phenomenon. Beyond the first relaxation, the injection continues until 100 ms and the appearance of quasi periodic relaxation phenomena can be noticed (Figure 3). Table 4.

For all three composites, the observation with low electron beam energy V, after a short injection time (less than relaxation time: tinj = 50 ms for composites (Si) and (W) and tinj = 20 ms for composite (AS)), shows the formation of perfect circular mirror images. These mirror images are due to the strong quantity of electrons Qt, locally trapped at the injection point. The curves 1/d = f(V) (Figure 7) are characterized by a deviation from the initial straight line. This phenomenon is linked to a lateral spreading of charges, along fibers, probably.2,6 It is more marked and occurs for lower potential values for composite (W) or (AS). Figure 7.
‘Mirror’ curve 1/d vs. electron beam potential V for the three composites after tinj = 50 ms for (W) and (Si) composites or after tinj = 20 ms for the (AS) composite. (Note that the (AS) composite releases before 50 ms.).

In conclusion, the (Si) composite is characterized by a strong capacity to trap electric charges, locally (Qt = 32 pC after 50 pC injected electrons) and without relaxation. Moreover, the diffusion of charges during the injection time is limited (QIC = 37 pC; Qt/QIC = 0.86 for tinj = 50 ms). The (AS) and (W) composites accept much fewer charges before relaxation and the diffusion of charges is more marked.

sec.title: Results and analysis of friction and wear properties
Friction coefficient evolution
sec.p:
The continuous recordings (180 points per cycle) of the average friction coefficient ‘μ’ as a function of the number of cycles N, for the three composites, are plotted in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Variation of the friction coefficient μ vs. number of friction cycles N, for composites (AS), (Si), and (W).

An increase in the friction coefficient is observed which tends to a plateau (μ = 0.6) for composite (AS), μ = 0.61 for composite (Si) and μ = 0.41 for composite (W). This increase is faster for composite (AS).

sec.title: Results and analysis of dielectric properties after friction
sec.p: The dielectric SEMME responses are characterized for each composite (AS, Si, and W) after 50 friction cycles, in the friction track (FZ) and outside the friction track (NFZ) of the plane (Figure 1) and compared to results obtained on virgin material (before friction) (Figure 3 and Table 4).

sec.title: (W) composite
sec.p:
Ground current curves Ig = f(time) are presented in Figure 9. Figure 9.
ICM curve Ig = f (injection time) for (W) composite, tinj = 100 ms. Electrons are injected on the plane inside the friction track (FZ), outside the friction track (NFZ), or on the virgin composite (before friction).

For composite (W), the virgin material relaxed at 53 ms injection time corresponding to Qr = 38.2 pC trapped charges. But, after friction, the material continues to accept electric charges for injection times higher than 100 ms (Table 4). Consequently, friction favors the trapping of electric charges and limits the relaxations, and this is true both in the friction track (FZ) and outside it (NFZ).

After friction, composite (W) is thus characterized by a strong aptitude to store electric charges. However, it is associated with a limited diffusion of charges confirmed by the fast disappearance of the mirror image (Vd = 600 V). Moreover, the observation of elliptic mirror images (long axis parallel to the fiber direction) proves that the spreading of the electric charges occurs in the direction of fibers, inducing an anisotropic distribution of trapped charges.9 It should be also underlined that the composite is modified as much within the friction track (FZ) as outside the friction track (NFZ). A similar result was obtained after friction of a polycrystalline alumina material.3,21

SEM observation (Figure 10) of the friction track after 50 friction cycles revealed the initiation of matrix microcracking. Interfacial fiber/matrix debonding is relatively limited. Figure 10.
SEM observation of the worn surface of the (W) composite after 50 friction cycles.

sec.title: (AS) composite
sec.p:
On the virgin material (before friction), composite (AS) relaxed at tr = 37 ms corresponding to Qr = 26.8 pC, trapped charges, whereas after friction, the material can retain Qr = 36.7 pC before relaxation at tr = 57.4 ms (NFZ) (Figure 11 and Table 4). In (FZ), the trapping is even more marked after friction, since there is no more release for 100 ms injection time. In this case, the friction favors the stable trapping of electric charges and delays relaxation. This is observed within the friction track (FZ) as well as outside the friction track (NFZ). Figure 11.
‘ICM’ curves Ig = f (injection time) for the (AS) composite, tinj = 100 ms. Electrons are injected on the plane, inside the friction track (FZ), outside the friction track (NFZ), or on the virgin composite (before friction).
The mirror observations show the formation of elliptic mirror images due to the preferential diffusion of the electric charges along the fiber/matrix interfaces.

Contrary to (W) and (Si) composites, SEM observation of the friction track after 50 friction cycles does not show any damage in the FZ, but after 200 cycles matrix cusps are observed (Figure 12), due to a cohesive fracture of the resin near the interface that is characteristic of good fiber/matrix adhesion. Figure 12.
SEM observation of the worn surface of (AS) composite after 200 friction cycles. Note that, after 50 friction cycles, the damage was not detectable unlike composites (W) and (Si) (Figures 10 and 14).

sec.title: (Si) composite
sec.p:
Before friction, composite (Si) is characterized by a strong aptitude to trap electric charges (Figure 3). The trapped electric charges induce a perfect circular mirror image which persists up to very high electron beam energy (Vd = 9000 V, Table 4). After friction (Figure 13), the curves Ig = f (times) in FZ are similar to those observed before friction. However, a diffusion of charges along fibers is confirmed by the appearance of a not very stable elliptic mirror (Vd = 600 V, Table 4). Figure 13.
‘ICM curve’ Ig = f (injection time); for (Si) composite, tinj = 100 ms. Electrons are injected on the plane, inside the friction track (FZ), outside the friction track (NFZ), or on the virgin composite (before friction).

It can thus be concluded that the friction of composite (Si) permits the spreading of the electric charges created by friction: the material traps the charges less deeply which favors their diffusion along the fiber direction and gives elliptic mirror images. As for the other composites, the (NFZ) is also affected, with the appearance of short relaxation phenomena during injection of electrons and a strong relaxation of charges after injection (Figure 13).

SEM observations (Figure 14) carried out on the worn surface of the composite after 50 friction cycles display debris formation by microcracking that tends to accumulate debris on the fiber/matrix interface and within the contact. The fibers are thus brought into direct contact with the antagonist: the surface layer of the resin was partially degraded and removed. It can be noticed moreover that fibers get broken and removed due to the failure of the interfacial bond between the matrix and the fibers. Figure 14.
SEM observation of the worn surface of the (Si) composite after 50 friction cycles.

sec.title: Mechanical and dielectric properties
sec.p: Our results confirm that the ultimate properties and the failure mode of the composite materials vary strongly with the nature of the fiber/matrix interface. The failure features of (AS) or (W) materials are characteristic of UD composites with good enough fiber/matrix adhesion. The failure for composite (Si) is specific and characteristic of a weakly bonded composite behavior (Table 3).

These results are consistent with ILSS measurements (Table 3). The failure occurs by intensive shear at the neutral plane and this kind of test is very often considered to be a good way to compare the quality of fiber/matrix adhesion in different composites.22,23 However, the result can be influenced by the presence of defects such as voids (porosity) that reduce ILSS values. These results should also be compared with dielectric measurements. During mechanical tests, charges are injected into the material. The surplus of charges will be trapped in the material: if this trapping is highly localized, for example close to the fiber/matrix interfaces, strong polarization energy will be stored. Its release will lead to damage of the material.

The sized silicone material (Si) has the very lowest ILSS value that is associated with strongly reduced fiber/matrix adhesion. From the dielectric point of view, it can store a significant quantity of electric charges, without release (Figure 3); therefore, a strong polarization energy which will lead to sudden delamination failure, close to the fiber/matrix interface.

The ILSS values of composite (W) are only slightly lower when compared to the values of composites that were subjected to a sizing treatment based on AS. This slight difference is probably due to the high level of porosity of the AS-sized composite that reduces ILSS values. From the dielectric point of view (Table 4 and Figure 3), these two materials have a rather close behavior: evacuation of the charges by release or diffusion, which limits the localization of the polarization energy. However, this effect is more significant for composite (AS) what leads to higher mechanical properties (Table 3).

sec.title: Tribology and dielectric properties
sec.p: First of all, let us recall that the evolution of the friction coefficient between insulating materials is directly related to the polarization energy stored in the material: an increase in the friction coefficient corresponds to the storage of polarization energy; on the other hand, a decrease in the friction coefficient corresponds to a release of energy.3,24–26 However, a trapping of electric charges corresponds to a storage of polarization energy (5 eV per trapped charge1) and, thus, to an increase in the friction coefficient, a detrapping of charges will lead to a lowering of the friction coefficient. If this detrapping is violent, wear will result by analogy with breakdown.4 This was shown on model materials (sapphire3,24–26) or industrial materials (alumina,4 zirconia27). For the composites, the role of the interfaces on the trapping–detrapping, of charges was confirmed. They will thus act directly, both on the evolution of the friction coefficient and on wear.

Before friction, composite (AS) accepts fewer electric charges with periodic relaxations (Figure 3), but, after friction (Figure 11), these relaxations are delayed and the material accepts more electric charges in FZ, corresponding to an increase in the stored polarization energy. This can explain the initial fast rise in the friction coefficient, unlike composite (W) or (Si). As it favors the trapping of charges, friction acts negatively on the dielectric behavior of the (AS) material. Fortunately, the charges, trapped in the FZ, are partly eliminated by secondary electron emission in the NFZ, which makes it possible to limit wear. The composite (AS) is thus characterized by a strong initial friction coefficient associated with low wear.

Composite (Si), before friction, is characterized by a strong capacity to trap electric charges (Figure 3). This property tends to decrease during friction, particularly in NFZ (Figure 13). In other words, it seems that friction improves the dielectric behavior of the material and helps the elimination of the charges outside the friction track. This explains the slower increase in the friction coefficient, the storage of polarization energy being limited.

For composite (W), which presents periodic relaxations before friction, the damage due to friction (i.e. microcracking of the matrix under the worn surface) delays the relaxation phenomena and favors the trapping of the electric charges without elimination of the charges, both in FZ and NFZ. To confirm this, classical (SEM) observations (Figure 15) prove that composite (W) presents, after friction, a significant quantity of electric charges trapped deeply in the direction of the fibers. In fact, during friction electric charges are created by triboelectrification24 and then injected and trapped under the surface in the two contacting bodies (plane and pin) of comparable nature. For composite (W), the charges of the same sign for the pin and the plane remain trapped and localized under the worn surface, inducing the establishment of a significant electrostatic repulsive force.21 Figure 15.
Electrostatic cushion (SEM).

As a consequence, a repulsive ‘'electrostatic cushion’' (Figure 15) is formed which could explain the low friction coefficient observed for the (W) composite, compared to that of the (AS) and (Si) composites (Figure 8) for which this effect is never observed, taking into account the significant diffusion of electric charges. In other words, for the (W) composite, the decrease in the friction coefficient is related to a reduction in the contact pressure, which opposes to the effect of the storage of polarization energy. Let us note that this phenomenon has already been observed during the friction of alumina implanted with zirconium ions.8,21

In any case, it is important to recall that the friction of the three composites modifies its dielectric behavior: in the friction track (FZ) and outside the friction track (NFZ) as well. This confirms the results observed previously on other GFRE6 or ceramics3,21 corresponding to a long distance dielectric effect.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The effect of the glass fiber/matrix interface in GFRE on dielectric behavior was studied using the ‘mirror’ method (SEMME) associated with measurements of ICM during the injection of electrons and, thus compared with mechanical and tribological properties.

From the mechanical point of view, material (Si) which has lower interfacial shear strength, presents a high capacity to trap charges. This leads, during the bending test, to a strong localization of the polarization energy along the fiber/matrix interface that can lead to catastrophic relaxation inducing nucleation of defects.

Conversely, composite (AS) allows the flow of the electric charges, which delocalizes the polarization energy and avoids disastrous relaxations. Composite (W) has an intermediate behavior as much from the dielectric point of view as from the mechanical point of view.

The tribological study revealed that the fiber/matrix interface nature plays a significant role in the diffusion of the electric charges, inducing a modification of the properties of the composite, not only in the FZ but also in the outside.
In parallel, friction creates new charge trapping sites permitting the reinforcement of the trapping (composites AS and W) or the spreading of the charges (composite Si).

To lower the friction coefficient, we can seek to increase local electric trapping increasing during friction to create an electrostatic cushion that will decrease the contact force and consequently the friction coefficient too, but wear can become pronounced: this is the particular case of composite (W). Apart from this case, it will be necessary to seek to decrease the stored polarization energy and consequently to choose a composite which allows the diffusion of the charges before and after friction, which is the case of the composite (AS).
